Olympic Sports Administration (IOC Dispu.time_to_resolution: Just over 1 month (resolves January 1, 2026; today is November 27, 2025)
Olympic Sports Administration (IOC Dispu.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Olympic Sports Administration and IOC Dispute Resolution Procedures, I bring deep knowledge of the process, structure, and legal precedents governing Olympic medal disputes, CAS appeals, and the limited but crucial role of the Swiss Federal Tribunal over CAS decisions. My background allows me to contextualize both the exceedingly rare base rate of successful post-Games medal appeal reversals and the particular procedural/legal nuances at play when a CAS decision is challenged at the Swiss Federal Tribunal level.
Olympic Sports Administration (IOC Dispu.status_quo: The bronze medal was awarded to Ana Barbosu of Romania following CAS ruling the US inquiry was four seconds late and upholding the Romanian appeal; the IOC has reallocated the medal, and although USA Gymnastics has challenged the CAS ruling and submitted further evidence, no decision overturning the CAS outcome has been reported as of November 27, 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Extraordinary rarity of CAS decisions being overturned by Swiss Federal Tribunal
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability: Base rate is approximately 0.3%-1% of all CAS awards ever successfully appealed; the Swiss Federal Tribunal only overturns CAS rulings in narrow procedural cases (violation of public policy, denial of right to be heard, etc.), almost never on substantive grounds.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Nature of the US complaint (timing/procedural error with video evidence)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability: If the US can clearly show that video evidence was not properly considered and there was procedural unfairness or a manifest error of law/procedure, it's one of the only contexts in which the Swiss Federal Tribunal might send the case back to CAS—but this is still very uncommon.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Swiss Federal Tribunal timelines and patterns in past appeals
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: Such appeals are typically resolved within 6-12 months, sometimes longer, but with only a month left and no known public decision, delay now favors No unless a ruling is imminent and leaks/reports would quickly emerge.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Close scrutiny/negative press and reputational risk for sporting bodies
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Marginal increase: Global attention and claims of discrimination sometimes motivate institutions to review or re-express procedural clarity, but this does NOT make legal reversal more likely—rather it increases visibility.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Procedural endgame: even a win by US at the Tribunal level likely only remands case to CAS, not an immediate overturn
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: The best realistic-case scenario for Chiles is the Swiss Federal Tribunal instructs CAS to rehear the case; outright overturning and ordering reallocation is exceedingly rare and almost unprecedented in Olympic medal cases.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: No sign of new credible reports about an overturn
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability: Media analysis up to November 25-27, 2025, indicates 'still pending,' 'in limbo,' and all credible gymnastics/Olympic reporting treats Barbosu as the official bronze medalist as of now.

Olympic Sports Administration (IOC Dispu.no_scenario: The Swiss Federal Tribunal either upholds the CAS ruling or does not issue any decision by January 1, 2026; as a result, Barbosu remains the official bronze medalist and all major outlets report that the US appeal was unsuccessful or unresolved.
Olympic Sports Administration (IOC Dispu.yes_scenario: Before January 1, 2026, the Swiss Federal Tribunal issues a reported decision overturning the CAS verdict—either on procedural fairness grounds or finding gross irregularity (e.g., US video evidence was demonstrably ignored); credible outlets report that the bronze reallocation has been reversed (likely pending a CAS rehearing or an IOC announcement reinstating Chiles as medalist).
Olympic Sports Administration (IOC Dispu.final_reasoning: Historically, the Swiss Federal Tribunal almost never overturns CAS awards: the published Bulletin gives win rates of 0.3%-1%, with most reversals on narrow grounds (e.g., serious breach of due process, not re-appraising facts). In the Chiles case there is a colorable argument—if the US can show clear evidence the inquiry was wrongly considered late and that key video evidence was ignored, Tribunal doctrine allows for a possible remand to CAS. However, the legal bar is high; in nearly all past Olympic medal disputes, no reversal has occurred after IOC/CAS action, and even a win would mean further CAS review, not reinstatement of the medal per se. The absence of any reporting (up to November 27, 2025) of a Tribunal decision, with the USAG and Chiles team still publicly stating 'waiting on a decision,' suggests nothing dramatic is imminent. Further, Swiss Tribunal outcomes are typically promptly reported given the public nature of Olympic controversies. Therefore, given timing, base rates, and the layers of procedural inertia, the likelihood that the Barbosu bronze is overturned before 2026 is very low—though not exactly zero due to the minute chance of a late, sensational Tribunal win.

Legal Arbitration (CAS Appeals and Arbit.time_to_resolution: Approximately 13 months (question closes on January 1, 2026; forecast date is November 27, 2025)
Legal Arbitration (CAS Appeals and Arbit.perspective_relevance: As an expert in CAS appeals and arbitration, I bring insight into (a) the rigid procedural standards of CAS, (b) the typical appellate path to the Swiss Federal Tribunal (SFT), (c) the legal bases and historical precedents for overturning CAS awards in Switzerland, and (d) how institutional inertia, deference to sports bodies, and procedural versus substantive fairness arguments affect such cases. This perspective is essential because the outcome hinges less on sporting fairness and more on narrow legal and procedural criteria, making the formal structure of the appeal process critical to the forecast.
Legal Arbitration (CAS Appeals and Arbit.status_quo: The CAS decision that stripped Jordan Chiles of her bronze remains in force. The IOC has awarded the medal to Ana Bărbosu of Romania. Chiles and USAG have appealed to the Swiss Federal Tribunal, but that court rarely overturns CAS awards (historically <1%). The medal is currently with Romania.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Swiss Federal Tribunal Overturn Rate
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability. With a historical overturn rate of less than 1%, and the SFT only accepting appeals on very narrow grounds (e.g., procedural violations, lack of due process, arbitrator conflict of interest), the bar is exceptionally high.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Alleged Procedural Irregularities (Timeliness, Conflict of Interest, New Video Evidence)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Marginally increases probability. Chiles/USAG allege improper process (evidence ignored, conflict of interest). If the SFT finds a grave procedural error (e.g., true denial of right to be heard), it could quash the decision and return it to CAS. However, even then, the medal is not assured to revert to the US—the case might simply be reheard.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: CAS Reluctance to Reopen Awards and SFT's Deference to CAS Autonomy
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Institutional reluctance is high unless a core principle of justice is alleged and proven. SFT almost never opines on the underlying facts or sporting rules.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Media, Political, and Social Pressure
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral to marginal. While there has been major media and social pressure, SFT has previously demonstrated resistance to outside influence. Unless procedural defects or bias are clear and legally significant, external pressures are largely irrelevant to SFT determinations.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Time Pressure and Likelihood of Decision Before 2026
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Given the SFT’s pace (multi-month to year-long timelines on appeals), and that we are already in late November 2025, the window is small for a favorable and timely concluding outcome.

Legal Arbitration (CAS Appeals and Arbit.no_scenario: The Swiss Federal Tribunal dismisses Chiles/USAG's appeal, finding no serious procedural violation or conflict of interest. No new credible evidence triggers a re-hearing, and the medal remains with Bărbosu/Romania up to and beyond January 1, 2026. Alternatively, the SFT simply declines to take the case before the close date, or upholds the CAS ruling, definitively ending options for further appeal.
Legal Arbitration (CAS Appeals and Arbit.yes_scenario: The SFT finds a serious procedural violation (e.g., improper exclusion of material evidence, proven arbitrator conflict), quashes the CAS award, and remands the case for rehearing—resulting in official credible sources stating the CAS judgment is overturned before January 1, 2026, and thus the reallocation is undone, at least temporarily. Alternatively, new evidence or a reconsideration leads CAS or the IOC, under SFT direction, to reverse the medal allocation prior to the close date.
Legal Arbitration (CAS Appeals and Arbit.final_reasoning: Drawing on my CAS/sports arbitration expertise, the outstanding features of this case are (a) the historical near-impossibility of overturning a CAS award via the Swiss Federal Tribunal (well under 1%), (b) the lack of credible new evidence that would meet SFT’s extremely high bar—right to be heard, bias, egregious injustice—especially since the core dispute is about a technical deadline that has already been adjudicated, and (c) the absence of any credible reporting (as of late November 2025) that suggests the SFT is poised to issue a ruling in Chiles’ favor imminently. Even if a procedural victory is achieved, this might simply result in a remand, not an immediate medal return to the US—meaning the conditions for a 'Yes' resolution (CAS decision overturned before 2026) are not only historically rare but also operationally unlikely given the time remaining and procedural hurdles. Thus, the base rate, current procedural posture, and Swiss sports legal precedent all support a strong 'No'.

European Sports Regulation (European Cou.time_to_resolution: Approximately 13 months, as question closes January 1, 2026.
European Sports Regulation (European Cou.perspective_relevance: As an expert in European Sports Regulation and the jurisprudence of the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) in sports disputes, my expertise is highly relevant because the challenge against the CAS ruling will, per international sporting protocol and Swiss law, funnel through the Swiss Federal Tribunal (SFT), which is the exclusive avenue of appeal for CAS decisions. Additionally, the ECHR may be a further avenue for claims relating to fair trial or discrimination, though with extremely low base rates of success within the time window. Familiarity with both the procedural and substantive grounds for review, as well as the historical base rates for such high-profile Olympic medal reallocations, provides deep insight.
European Sports Regulation (European Cou.status_quo: The status quo is that the bronze medal has been reallocated from US gymnast Jordan Chiles to Romania’s Ana Barbosu after CAS ruled the US appeal was submitted late. The IOC formalized this reallocation, and all subsequent appeals have so far failed to alter this outcome. Chiles and USAG have appealed to the Swiss Federal Tribunal, and the case remains pending as of November 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Successful Appeals of CAS Awards to Swiss Federal Tribunal
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability. The cited CAS Bulletin clarifies that only about 0.3% of CAS awards are overturned by the SFT, and appeals almost always fail even when formally accepted because the Tribunal reviews only extremely narrow procedural grounds—typically not the merits of sporting disputes.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Nature of the Complaint (Procedural, not Substantive Sporting Merit)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The SFT examines only violations of due process, jurisdiction, public policy, and (rarely) breaches of fundamental rights, not whether the inquiry should have been accepted. The dispute centers on a timing/procedure question, which is an archetype for SFT deference to the sporting authorities and CAS.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Allegations of Conflict of Interest and Denial of Evidence (Video Evidence, Potential ECHR Aspects)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Marginally increases probability. Chiles’ camp alleges the CAS panel president having ties to Romania and that video evidence was not properly heard. While these are non-frivolous procedural complaints, the SFT rarely grants relief on such grounds unless there is clear, manifest breach of justice or evidence the process was fundamentally unfair.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Time Pressure and International Attention
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Marginal effect upwards. Because this case received sustained media and political attention (including racism allegations and threatened diplomatic incidents), the SFT may feel pressure to give the appeal close scrutiny, but typically resists being swayed by public sentiment in decisions.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Precedent of Previous Olympic Medal Reallocations Post-CAS
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Historical precedents nearly always see initial CAS/IOC decisions stand, except in clear, egregious procedural violations (usually involving doping, not technical sports rules). There is no precedent for SFT ordering a CAS reversal in a scoring challenge.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Timing (Swiss Federal Tribunal Known for Lengthy Process)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly decreases probability. These appeals often take over a year and, compared to the remaining 13 months to resolution, it is plausible—but not guaranteed—that a verdict will issue in time. If the SFT sends it back to CAS, the subsequent process would also need to be completed before the deadline.

European Sports Regulation (European Cou.no_scenario: The Swiss Federal Tribunal either rejects the appeal on procedural grounds (as is usual), finds no breach of due process, jurisdiction, or public policy, or issues a ruling too late to allow further review and reversal before January 1, 2026. Alternatively, if the process is ongoing with no final decision, or if all appeals are exhausted and the original outcome is upheld, the answer is No.
European Sports Regulation (European Cou.yes_scenario: In an exceptional outcome, the SFT finds (for example) that the CAS panel’s composition breached impartiality requirements or that denial of key video evidence was a fundamental procedural error. The SFT annuls the CAS ruling, remands for a reconsideration, and the CAS (in a new panel) determines the inquiry was on time, awarding the bronze medal back to Chiles before the deadline. Alternatively, the SFT sets aside the CAS decision and directly rules in favor of Chiles, which almost never happens.
European Sports Regulation (European Cou.final_reasoning: The overwhelming weight of history, the formal structure of the relevant procedures, ultra-low base rates (0.3% or less of CAS awards overturned), and the degree to which the SFT restricts itself to narrowly defined procedural violations severely restrict the odds of the medal being reallocated back to the US before 2026. Although the case involves allegations of procedural unfairness (such as video evidence and conflict of interest), such claims are rarely successful at the SFT unless the violations are flagrant—and current reporting does not suggest so. Further, there is no reported SFT decision yet, and the typical duration of such appeals means a decision could arrive late. If the SFT sends the case back to a fresh CAS panel, a reversal might still be possible within 13 months, but this would be unprecedented in an Olympic medal allocation due to a sporting procedure (rather than, for example, a doping violation). The moral/political controversy (racism, etc.) is unlikely to sway the Swiss judiciary. On balance, the odds are extremely low, but not zero, especially as there is a formal right to appeal and ongoing media and legal advocacy. My probability reflects both the extremely low base rate and the existence of non-frivolous procedural complaints.

Sports Law (Court of Arbitration for Spo.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Sports Law and Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) jurisprudence, I bring deep expertise on the legal mechanisms for overturning CAS decisions, success rates of CAS appeals (especially before the Swiss Federal Tribunal), and procedural nuances relevant to Olympic dispute resolution.
Sports Law (Court of Arbitration for Spo.status_quo: The CAS decision—vacating Chiles’ inquiry and reassigning the bronze to Barbosu—stands. CAS has refused to reopen the case, and medal allocation has shifted to Romania. USA Gymnastics is appealing to the Swiss Federal Tribunal, but the CAS and IOC have deemed the decision final for administrative/operational purposes.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Swiss Federal Tribunal (SFT) success rate
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Historically, less than 1% of SFT appeals against CAS awards are successful, with only a handful (about five) since 1984. The SFT is deferential, intervening almost exclusively on narrow procedural or jurisdictional grounds, not merits.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Timeliness and exhaustion of remedies
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. News reports indicate that a request to CAS to revisit its own award was denied, presumably for lack of jurisdiction; the SFT is now the exclusive route—if the SFT denies the appeal, the matter is effectively closed.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Nature of alleged process failures
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. The appeal to the SFT raises specific claims: denial of a fair hearing, potentially disregarded evidence (video proof of timely submission), and an alleged conflict of interest by the panel head. The SFT will only act if there is a manifest violation of public policy or due process—a high but not insurmountable bar, especially if egregious procedural lapses are proven.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Media and political attention
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Minimal increase. This case is high-profile, with allegations of racism, widespread controversy, and cross-national interest (USA, Romania). While courts are to act independently, extreme international scrutiny might prompt extra diligence. Still, this rarely results in changed legal outcomes at this level.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: New evidence (video documentation)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Marginal increase. If USA Gymnastics’ new video evidence is compelling and it can be shown that it was excluded or improperly disregarded due to a procedural failure, this presents one of the rare paths SFT might endorse—if the process below was so defective it breached fundamental fairness.

Sports Law (Court of Arbitration for Spo.no_scenario: The Swiss Federal Tribunal, consistent with precedent, finds that there was no breach of due process or public policy, or the procedural default is not egregious enough to intervene. The challenge by USA Gymnastics is denied, and all administrative and judicial avenues are exhausted. Romania retains the bronze medal allocation through January 1, 2026.
Sports Law (Court of Arbitration for Spo.yes_scenario: The SFT finds a gross procedural irregularity (for example, clear denial of the right to be heard, improper exclusion of vital evidence, or a disqualifying conflict of interest). The SFT annuls the CAS award and remands the dispute for rehearing. Subsequent CAS proceedings lead to a reversal, restoring the bronze medal to the US (or, equivalently for this question, the CAS decision to reallocate is overturned before January 1, 2026).
Sports Law (Court of Arbitration for Spo.final_reasoning: Base rates for successful appeals against CAS rulings are extremely low—historically, well below 1%. This is supported by the CAS Bulletin and jurisprudence. The SFT is limited to reviewing whether fundamental procedural rights or public policy principles were violated, not the merits of the underlying scoring dispute. In the present case, the US appeal is grounded in specific procedural allegations (denial of a fair hearing and improper handling of evidence), which slightly increase the likelihood relative to a pure merits challenge. The high profile of the case and the existence of controversy (alleged bias, racism, new evidence) are insufficient on their own but do marginally elevate the possibility compared to an average case. However, the SFT’s posture remains deferential, and the threshold for overturning is very high. There is no indication that a decision is imminent or that the SFT has found violations so egregious as to warrant intervention, and appeals can take many months. As of late November 2025, there are no reports of any reversal or new SFT ruling. Thus, the probability that the CAS decision to reallocate the bronze medal from the US to Romania will be overturned before January 1, 2026, remains very low—though not zero due to some colorable procedural allegations and capable legal representation.

Sports Law (Olympic Charter Provisions).perspective_relevance: As an expert on the Olympic Charter and its legal interpretation, particularly in the context of Olympic sports adjudication, dispute resolution, and medal reallocations, I can analyze likely outcomes based on the typical process and success rates for appeals post-CAS decisions. My understanding of how the Olympic Charter, the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), and the Swiss Federal Tribunal interact, as well as precedent in similar disputes, is directly relevant here.
Sports Law (Olympic Charter Provisions).status_quo: As of now, the bronze medal in women’s floor exercise at the Paris 2024 Olympics stands officially awarded to Ana Bǎrbosu (Romania) after the CAS ruled the US appeal was too late. USA Gymnastics and Chiles have appealed unsuccessfully to CAS; a final appeal to the Swiss Federal Supreme Court is pending. No medals have been re-re-reallocated.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: CAS Decision Finality and Appeal Success Rate
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Drastically decreases probability. CAS decisions are extremely rarely overturned by the Swiss Federal Tribunal (success rate historically below 1%). Most such appeals are dismissed unless there is proven procedural unfairness or jurisdictional error, not a review of facts.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Nature of Allegations (Procedural versus Merits)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. The US side argues that there was a procedural defect (late/incomplete evidence review, possible conflict of interest). Procedural errors are one of the very few grounds Swiss courts may consider, so this is marginally more viable than a pure sporting/score dispute.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Political and Reputational Pressure (Allegations of Bias/Racism)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. Although Swiss courts are insulated from public and reputational pressure, allegations of racial bias, irregular process, and claims of significant injustice could prompt especially careful review.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Timeliness and Exhaustion of Appeals
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly decreases probability. The process has nearly exhausted all appeal options, and there is little time left for further rounds. The Swiss Federal Tribunal is known to be rigorous but is unlikely to overturn and remand a case this late in the cycle.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Swiss Federal Tribunal Precedent and Mandate
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability. The SFT’s mandate in sports arbitration is only to review the consistency of the arbitral process with Swiss law and procedural fairness, not the sporting merits nor evidentiary disputes. Both Olympic Charter and CAS rules are robustly designed to withstand such reviews.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent News and Signals
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral to slightly negative. The latest reports indicate Chiles's camp is still waiting but no leaks or positive signs of an impending pro-Chiles decision have emerged even weeks before the deadline.

Sports Law (Olympic Charter Provisions).no_scenario: The most probable: The Swiss Federal Tribunal either declines to hear the appeal, or reviews and affirms CAS’s decision, finding no actionable procedural defect or conflict of interest so egregious as to warrant reversal. The medal remains with Barbosu, with closure by or before January 1, 2026.
Sports Law (Olympic Charter Provisions).yes_scenario: Improbable but possible: The Swiss Federal Tribunal finds a serious procedural error by the CAS panel (e.g., egregious conflict of interest or manifest denial of right to be heard), annuls the award and remands the case to CAS, or rarely, rules so as to affect the medal’s allocation in a way that overturns the outcome before January 1, 2026.
Sports Law (Olympic Charter Provisions).final_reasoning: Base rates for successful appeals from CAS to the Swiss Federal Tribunal are under 1%. While the Chiles case does allege potential procedural errors—claims the panel head had a conflict of interest and insufficient consideration of new evidence—these types of arguments almost never succeed unless the process was egregiously flawed, not simply unwise or contentious. The window for decision is closing rapidly; the Swiss court has shown no overt signs of willingness to act dramatically nor any leaks suggestive of a reversal. There’s no indication that international or political pressure (even high-profile racism claims) will sway a Swiss legal panel away from established precedent, although it could lead to especially rigorous review. Factoring in the procedural nuances and the slight increase in legal attention (but not precedent), the probability is fractionally above the historical rate, but remains very low.

International Sports Governance (Interna.perspective_relevance: As an expert in International Sports Governance and specifically International Gymnastics Federation (FIG) rules, I have unique insight into the technical regulations governing gymnastics competitions, judiciary processes of international sporting disputes, typical timelines/probabilities for successful appeals at the CAS and the Swiss Federal Tribunal, and how flagging procedural irregularities and evidence submission standards operate at the top levels of Olympic sport. I also understand how precedents affect medal reallocations and the degree of finality in CAS judicial decisions.
International Sports Governance (Interna.status_quo: The bronze medal in the women’s floor exercise at Paris 2024 is currently allocated to Romania (Ana Bǎrbosu), following the CAS overturning Jordan Chiles’ result and the IOC’s reallocation. USA Gymnastics has appealed to the Swiss Federal Supreme Court, but no overturning of the CAS decision has occurred as of November 27, 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Historical Overturn Rate for CAS Awards by Swiss Federal Tribunal
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. CAS arbitral decisions are rarely overturned. The historical success rate for appeals is extremely low—around 1% of appeals, or 0.3% of all cases decided by CAS, according to CAS itself. This makes overturning the reallocation highly improbable barring clear legal/procedural violations.

If clear and egregious process errors are evident, this is the narrow legal window where such an appeal could succeed.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Timing and CAS/FIG Precedence
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Usually, medal reallocations stand unless gross justice errors are found.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Media and Political Pressure
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Minor increase. perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability for Yes outcome: With about a month left, and the expected pace of Swiss Federal Tribunal decisions, there is limited time for a ruling and, if positive for Chiles, remanding to CAS and for a reversal to be officially implemented before January 1, 2026.

International Sports Governance (Interna.no_scenario: The Swiss Federal Supreme Court, after reviewing the appeal, issues a verdict upholding the CAS ruling (either finding no breach of minimum procedural standards, or declining to intervene on substance or timing), or delays past Jan 1, 2026. CAS then rapidly issues a new award in Chiles’ favor, IOC reallocates the bronze to the US, and credible news sources report the reallocation—all before Jan 1, 2026.
International Sports Governance (Interna.final_reasoning: Base rates strongly discourage expecting a successful challenge of a CAS award: overturning such decisions is extremely rare (historical rate below 1%). The only plausible route is demonstrating a clear and fundamental breach of due process—which is a high legal bar and, per reports, may depend on proving the CAS panel improperly disregarded key evidence or had provable conflicts. Media and political controversy, including claims of racial motivation, may ensure the case is scrutinized, but Swiss courts are unlikely to be influenced unless procedural irregularity is unequivocally demonstrated. The improbability is even higher given the short and closing time window for the Swiss Tribunal to both rule and, if favorable to Chiles, for that new ruling to be processed by CAS/IOC and for the medal to be officially reallocated within the ~35 days remaining. While there is ongoing legal action and some circumstantial possibility due to the video evidence and conflict claims, I assess continued Romanian ownership of the bronze medal is the overwhelming likelihood. I assign a slightly higher probability than the pure base rate due to the unusual (potentially provable) procedural claims and the high-profile international context, but it remains a low-probability event.

International Sports Governance (World A.no_scenario: The Swiss Federal Tribunal either upholds the CAS ruling or has not issued a final decision by Jan 1, 2026, meaning the bronze medal remains with Bǎrbosu, and Chiles' last avenues for overturn have failed or are still pending.

International Sports Governance (World A.final_reasoning: Given the extremely low historical base rate of CAS awards being overturned by the Swiss Federal Tribunal (about 0.3–1%), the lack of precedent for such reversals in non-doping/sporting judgment issues, and the short time window before the close of 2025, the chances of an outright 'Yes' are small. The case has garnered sustained media and political attention, and Chiles' team has made plausible allegations of process problems. Nonetheless, the legal standard is very high; the Swiss Tribunal traditionally avoids second-guessing arbitral awards unless there is clear evidence of procedural injustice—and even then, most cases result in remands at best, not direct reversals. question_details.title: Will the decision to reallocate the bronze medal in the women's floor exercise at the 2024 Paris Olympics from the US to Romania be overturned before 2026?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-08-20 17:22:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/27208). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

During the women's floor exercise final at the 2024 Paris Olympics, Jordan Chiles of the United States initially finished in fifth place. However, her coach filed an inquiry regarding her difficulty score, which resulted in Chiles being awarded an additional tenth of a point, moving her into third place and earning her the bronze medal.

Romania, whose gymnasts Ana Barbosu and Sabrina Maneca-Voinea finished fourth and fifth respectively after the inquiry, protested the decision, claiming that Chiles' inquiry was filed too late. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) agreed with Romania's protest and vacated Chiles' inquiry, officially revising her score and placing her back in fifth place.

As a result, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) announced that it would reallocate the bronze medal to Ana Bǎrbosu. However, USA Gymnastics has [challenged](https://www.npr.org/2024/08/11/g-s1-16509/us-gymnast-jordan-chiles-bronze-medal-return) the CAS ruling, submitting video evidence that allegedly proves Chiles' inquiry was filed within the allowed time frame.

[CNN reports](https://www.cnn.com/2024/08/12/sport/jordan-chiles-bronze-olympics-controversy-explained/index.html) that the CAS does not have authority to revisit the case.

A [CAS Bulletin](https://www.tas-cas.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Bulletin202_2011.pdf) published in 2011 explores the issue of CAS appeals in more detail in the section "Appeals against Arbitral Awards by the CAS", starting on page 19 (pdf page 22). The section describes that CAS appeals are heard by the Swiss Federal Tribunal, which is essentially the supreme court of Switzerland, the particular conditions under which an appeal is typically heard, and says the following about the frequency and success of appeals:

>Nowadays the CAS assumes that an appeal will be filed against approximately 10% of its arbitral awards. However, the success rate of these appeals is low. Since the CAS was established in 1984 only five appeals against CAS arbitral awards have succeeded. On average only 1% of all appeals against CAS arbitral awards were successful in 2009 and 2010. If one expresses the number of successful appeals as a percentage of all of the arbitral awards that have so far been delivered by the CAS (1984 – 2010), the success rate is 0.3%.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":27208,"question_id":27208}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before January 1, 2026, credible sources report that the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS)'s decision to reallocate the bronze medal in the women's floor exercise at the 2024 Paris Olympics from the Jordan Chiles of the United States to Ana Bǎrbosu of Romania has been overturned on appeal.

The question will resolve as **No** if no such decision has been announced before January 1, 2026, or if before January 1, 2026, a higher court hears an appeal and announces that it has upheld the original decision, and credible sources report that no higher level of appeal remains.

**International Ski Federation's Attempt to Influence Athletes Fails; Case Reaches CAS**
The International Ski Federation (FIS) decided in October 2024 to exclude athletes from 'aggressor countries' from international competitions, including the current season. The Russian Ski Federation appealed this decision to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), which is scheduled to hear its case on December 1, 2025. The ruling is expected no later than December 10, 2025. FIS announced the decision on October 21, shortly before the start of the Alpine Ski World Cup. Russia holds strong positions in FIS disciplines, particularly in cross-country skiing. In its CAS appeal, the Russian federation seeks the same participation conditions under FIS as those granted by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) for the 2026 Winter Olympics, where athletes from Russia and Belarus may compete under the neutral designation AIN. Prior to the decision, FIS attempted to influence national federations by sending a questionnaire asking whether athletes from aggressor nations should be reinstated, arguing that athletes should not be discriminated against based on birthplace. However, when FIS leadership lacked sufficient support, it issued a brief statement announcing the exclusion of Russian and Belarusian athletes from the 2026 Winter Olympics qualification, without commentary from its president, Johan Eliasch, who reportedly avoided commenting on what he viewed as a personal and painful defeat. The statement lacked the usual official remarks from FIS leadership, such as those from the president or general secretary.

**Pernilla Wiberg on Her Controversial Stance: 'It Has Been Jättetufft'**
Pernilla Wiberg, a 55-year-old Swedish sports figure, expressed her disagreement with the International Olympic Committee's (IOC) 2022 decision to exclude Russian and Belarusian athletes from international competition following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. In an interview with Expressen, she stated that the IOC had violated its own statutes and emphasized the importance of democratic principles, including the right to voice opinions, even when controversial. She described the backlash she received on social media as 'jättetufft' (extremely tough), noting the ease with which people now post harmful content anonymously. Despite the criticism, Wiberg affirmed her stance, saying she spoke from a human and principled perspective based on IOC regulations and the athletes' rights. She revealed she has blocked specific words on her social media to manage online harassment. While the IOC has since allowed Russian and Belarusian athletes to compete under a neutral flag for the Paris 2024 and Winter Olympics, the International Ski and Snowboard Federation (FIS) has extended the ban on Russian and Belarusian skiers, who are currently excluded from the Milano-Cortina 2026 Olympics. The Russian Ski Federation has appealed the decision to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), which expects to deliver a ruling by December 10, 2025.

**Jordan Chiles' medal controversy explained as Olympian gears up for DWTS Season 34 finale**
Jordan Chiles, who originally won a bronze medal in the individual floor event at the 2024 Paris Olympics, had her medal stripped following a scoring inquiry, with the medal reassigned to Romania’s Ana Barbosu. The decision sparked widespread debate in gymnastics circles and online. Chiles addressed the incident at the ESPY Awards on July 16, stating she remains committed to embracing her Paris experience and that she views her performance as a bronze-level effort regardless of the final ruling. She has not yet decided whether to return for the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics, noting she plans to complete one more year of college before making a formal decision. As of November 25, 2025, she has not provided any new public updates on her Olympic future. Chiles is currently competing on Dancing with the Stars (DWTS) Season 34, where she and partner Ezra Sosa are in a close race for the finale. For the finale, they will perform a paso doble to Rihanna’s 'Breakin’ Dishes' and a freestyle to Normani’s 'Motivation.' Her public focus remains on the show and finishing the season strongly, even as the Paris medal controversy continues to be discussed by fans.

**Russian Gymnast Angelina Melnikova Removed from German Club After Supporting Putin**
Russian gymnast Angelina Melnikova, an Olympic and World Championships gold medalist, has been removed from competing for the German club TSV Tittmoning-Chemnitz in the German elite gymnastics league. The decision followed controversy over her public support for Russian President Vladimir Putin and the war in Ukraine, which reportedly violated the International Gymnastics Federation (FIG) neutrality rules. Melnikova, 25, signed with the club earlier in November and made her debut at the second-to-last league event in Esslingen, Germany, on November 15. Although no protests occurred at the time, the city mayor, Matthias Klopfer, urged the club to reconsider her participation. On November 25, club coach Tatjana Bachmayer confirmed to Deutsche Welle that Melnikova would not compete in the final event in Heidelberg on November 29. The club's board made the decision to protect its coaches, citing a 'very tense' two-week period. FIG granted Melnikova 'neutral' status in March 2024, allowing her to compete internationally despite rules prohibiting 'active support' of the war in Ukraine. She has been photographed with the Russian military 'Z' symbol, which FIG explicitly prohibits. Melnikova also ran in Russian local elections as a candidate for United Russia, a party aligned with Putin. She declined to discuss her neutral status during an interview with SWR, responding with 'No comment.' Since 2023, FIG has permitted Russian and Belarusian athletes to compete as neutrals, and three such athletes participated in the 2024 Paris Olympics trampoline events. Melnikova won two golds and one silver at the World Championships in Jakarta in October 2024, including the all-around title, prompting Putin to congratulate her on her 'brilliant achievements.' FIG has refused to comment on individual cases, stating it does not issue individual explanations. The German gymnastics league affirmed its compliance with FIG regulations.

**Angelina Melnikowa's German Turnliga Campaign Ends Amid Political Controversy**
Angelina Melnikowa, the Russian gymnast and self-identified supporter of Russian President Vladimir Putin, will not participate in the German Turnliga (DTL) final on November 29, 2025, as confirmed by TSV Tittmoning-Chemnitz coach Tatjana Bachmayer. Her planned debut in the final, following a contract signed earlier in November for the last two Bundesliga events of the season, was halted due to controversy over her political affiliations and visible support for Russia’s war in Ukraine, including being photographed with the military symbol 'Z'. Although the club initially stated the signing was based solely on sporting merit—'We don’t want to make a political statement,' Bachmayer said—internal pressure and the intense backlash led the club’s board to make the final decision to exclude her. The club cited the need to protect its coaching staff, calling the past two weeks 'very intense.' While the club has not officially confirmed the termination of Melnikowa’s contract, her participation in future Bundesliga events is now effectively ended. The International Gymnastics Federation (FIG) granted her 'neutral athlete' status in March 2024, allowing her to compete internationally despite rules prohibiting athletes who actively support the war in Ukraine. Melnikowa has refused to comment on the matter, stating 'No comment!' in a SWR interview. She had been banned from international competition since the start of the war in 2022, missing major events including the 2022 and 2023 World Championships, the 2022 and 2023 European Championships, and the 2024 Paris Olympics. Her return as a neutral athlete was marked by a gold medal performance at the 2024 World Championships in Jakarta, where she won two golds and a silver. Russian President Putin publicly congratulated her on her 'outstanding performance.' The DTL affirmed it follows FIG regulations, and the FIG declined to comment on individual cases.

**Seven-Time Olympic Medalist Penny Oleksiak Suspended for Two Years Over Anti-Doping Violations**
Canadian swimmer Penny Oleksiak, a seven-time Olympic medalist, has been suspended for two years due to violations of anti-doping rules, according to the International Testing Agency (ITA). The suspension stems from three missed whereabouts failures within a 12-month period between October 2024 and June 2025. In July 2025, Oleksiak voluntarily accepted a provisional suspension and did not contest the arbitral decision, agreeing to the consequences proposed by the ITA. She will be ineligible until July 2027 and will lose all individual results achieved since June 16, 2025. This includes her absence from the Paris 2024 Olympics, where she did not win medals, unlike her four medals in Rio 2016 and three in Tokyo 2020 (held in 2021 due to the pandemic). According to Suzanne Paulins, executive director of Canada's national swimming team, Oleksiak’s violations were unintentional and no prohibited substances were used, but the anti-doping rules are in place to ensure fair competition. The decision may be appealed to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), but it does not prevent Oleksiak from aiming for a fourth consecutive Olympic appearance at Los Angeles 2028. Oleksiak, 25, became the first athlete born in the 21st century to win an individual Olympic gold medal in Rio 2016, tying with American Simone Manuel in the 100-meter freestyle final. She remains Canada’s most decorated Olympic swimmer, matching the seven medals of male sprinter Andre De Grasse.

**Russian Gymnast Angelina Melnikova Excluded from German League Final Over Ukraine War Support**
Russian gymnast Angelina Melnikova will not participate in the season's final of the German top-tier gymnastics league, despite having signed with TSV Tittmoning-Chemnitz in early November and making her debut in Esslingen, Germany, on November 15. Her participation sparked controversy due to her public support for Russian President Vladimir Putin and her endorsement of the war in Ukraine, which violates the International Gymnastics Federation (FIG) neutrality rules. The city mayor of Esslingen, Matthias Klopfer, urged the club to reconsider her inclusion, though no protests occurred at the time. On November 25, 2025, TSV Chemnitz coach Tatjana Bachmayer confirmed to Deutsche Welle that Melnikova would not compete in the final in Heidelberg on November 29, citing a need to focus on preparation and describing the past two weeks as 'very tense.' The club’s board made the decision primarily to protect the coaches. FIG granted Melnikova 'neutral' status in March 2024, allowing her to compete internationally despite rules prohibiting active support for the military conflict in Ukraine. She has been photographed with Russian military symbols and participated in Russian local elections as a representative of the pro-Putin United Russia party. She refused to comment on her neutral status during an interview with SWR, stating 'no comment.' Since 2023, FIG has permitted Russian and Belarusian athletes to compete as neutrals, and three such athletes competed in the 2024 Paris Olympics trampoline events. FIG declined to explain its decision regarding Melnikova, citing policy not to comment on individual cases. German gymnastics league officials stated their adherence to FIG regulations. Melnikova achieved significant success after returning to international competition, winning two gold medals—including the all-around title—and one silver at the World Championships in Jakarta, Indonesia, in October 2025, earning congratulations from Putin, who praised her 'glorious achievements.'

**Angelina Melnikowa's German Turnliga Campaign Ends Amid Political Controversy**
Angelina Melnikowa, the Russian gymnast and self-identified supporter of Russian President Vladimir Putin, will not participate in the German Turnliga (DTL) final on November 29, 2025, as confirmed by TSV Tittmoning-Chemnitz coach Tatjana Bachmayer. Her planned debut in the final, following a contract signed earlier in November for the last two Bundesliga events of the season, was halted due to controversy over her political affiliations and visible support for Russia’s war in Ukraine, including being photographed with the military symbol 'Z'. Although the club initially stated the signing was based solely on sporting merit—'We don’t want to make a political statement,' Bachmayer said—internal pressure and the intense backlash led the club’s board to make the final decision to exclude her. The club cited the need to protect its coaching staff, calling the past two weeks 'very intense.' While the club has not officially confirmed the termination of Melnikowa’s contract, her participation in future Bundesliga events is now effectively ended. The International Gymnastics Federation (FIG) granted her 'neutral athlete' status in March 2024, allowing her to compete internationally despite rules prohibiting athletes who actively support the war in Ukraine. Melnikowa has refused to comment on the matter, stating 'No comment!' in a SWR interview. She had been banned from international competition since the start of the war in 2022, missing major events including the 2022 and 2023 World Championships, the 2022 and 2023 European Championships, and the 2024 Paris Olympics. Her return as a neutral athlete was marked by a gold medal performance at the 2024 World Championships in Jakarta, where she won two golds and a silver. Russian President Putin publicly congratulated her on her 'outstanding performance.' The DTL affirmed it follows FIG regulations, and the FIG declined to comment on individual cases.

**Cas to Hear Russian Appeal on Olympic Participation on December 1**
The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) will hear the Russian Ski Federation's appeal on December 1, 2025, in a expedited proceeding. The appeal challenges the decision by the International Ski and Snowboard Federation (FIS), which, despite efforts by FIS President Johan Eliasch to align with the IOC's stance allowing individual Russian and Belarusian athletes to compete at the 2026 Winter Olympics in Milano/Cortina, was rejected by the FIS executive board one month prior. The Russian Ski Federation submitted the appeal to Cas in Lausanne, Switzerland, seeking a review of FIS's decision. Cas announced that the parties will be heard via video conference on December 1, 2025, and will issue an operational decision (without reasoning) by no later than December 10, 2025. The 2026 Winter Olympics will take place from February 4 to February 22, 2026, and will be broadcast by SVT, TV4, and HBO Max.

**US Olympics star makes racism claim after having 2024 medal rescinded**

**Jordan Chiles addresses question of whether racism was related to...**
US Olympic gymnast Jordan Chiles addressed whether racism played a role in the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) decision to rescind her bronze medal from the 2024 Paris Olympics women's floor exercise final. In a September 2024 interview at the Forbes Power Women's Summit and a November 2025 podcast appearance on 'Baby, this is Keke Palmer,' Chiles stated that she initially did not consider racism as a factor until she began receiving racially charged online abuse, including threats to take her life. She noted that the historic 'all-Black' podium—featuring Chiles, Simone Biles, and Rebeca Andrade—was rare and apparently unwelcome to some, saying, 'they didn't want to see three beautiful Black women standing on that podium.' Chiles claimed the incident was not about the medal but about her skin color. The controversy began when a US coach appealed a scoring decision, leading to a score adjustment that moved Chiles from fifth to third place, displacing Romania’s Ana Barbosu, who reacted with visible distress. After CAS ruled the appeal was submitted past the one-minute deadline, the IOC required Chiles to return the medal. Chiles and Team USA have appealed the CAS decision, arguing that the appeal was submitted on time and supported by video evidence, and that the official who ruled on the case had ties to Romania. Chiles also filed an appeal with the Swiss Federal Supreme Court, claiming she was denied a fair hearing and that video evidence was not properly considered. The CAS and USOPC jointly criticized the International Gymnastics Federation (FIG) for lacking proper procedures, stating that 'a great deal of heartache would have been avoided' with better mechanisms. Barbosu, who received the bronze medal after the reversal, expressed sympathy for Chiles and teammate Sabrina Maneca-Voinea, emphasizing the Olympic spirit. Chiles is now competing at UCLA, while Barbosu competes at Stanford, with their teams set to face each other on March 7, 2026.

**Jordan Chiles medal saga: Olympic gymnastics bronze still in limbo a year later**
One year after the 2024 Paris Olympics, Jordan Chiles' bronze medal is still in limbo due to a controversial ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). Chiles' coach Cecile Landi initially appealed the decision, arguing that Chiles had not been given full credit for a tour jete, a leap. summary: All experts converged on a very low probability (2–4%) that the decision to reallocate the bronze medal in the women’s floor exercise at the 2024 Paris Olympics from the US to Romania will be overturned before January 1, 2026. Their analyses unanimously emphasized the extremely rare historic success rate (<1%, often 0.3%) for overturning Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) awards via appeal to the Swiss Federal Tribunal (SFT), which only acts on narrow procedural errors rather than merits of sporting disputes. While the US appeal cites procedural concerns—timing, alleged improper exclusion of new video evidence, and possible conflict of interest—experts agree these claims slightly increase but do not substantially alter the overwhelmingly negative base rates. The existing high-profile nature of the case, international media attention, and allegations of bias were seen as insufficient to sway the SFT, which is institutionally resistant to external pressure. Experts also noted the short time frame left for a decision. The most likely scenario—supported across all fields (sports law, arbitration, Olympic administration, and governance)—is that the SFT upholds the CAS ruling or fails to rule before the deadline, leaving the medal with Romania. Even in the unlikely event of a procedural win for the US, the process would likely involve a remand and rehearing, which would be difficult to complete before 2026. Thus, prospects for a reversal within the time limit are extremely slim, reflected in consensus probabilities of 2–4%.
